title.narrative: CoE Action against Economic Crime/Money Laundering in Serbia
CoE Åtgärder mot Ekonomisk Brottslighet/Penningtvätt i Serbien

description.narrative:
I maj 2019 kontaktade Europarådets (CoE) kontor i Belgrad ambassaden med ett konceptdokument om förebyggande av penningtvätt och finansiering av terrorism i Serbien. Förslaget utvecklades vidare i samråd med de viktigaste nationella intressenterna. Det slutliga förslaget överlämnades till Sida i oktober 2019.
Förslaget belyser ett område som är mycket relevant i den nuvarande fasen av Serbiens reformprocess som drivs av EUs integrationsförhandlingar. Den tar upp de upplevda brister på detta område och bygger på en befintlig övervaknings ram, vilket ökar dess genomförbarhet och stöder ägarskap.
Bidraget bedöms som relevant, eftersom det följer nationellt fastställda prioriteringar och är i linje med Serbiens och Sveriges strategiska mål. Det ligger i linje med Resultatstrategi för reformsamarbete med Östeuropa, Västra Balkan och Turkiet för perioden 2014-2020, med avseende på resultatområde 2. Strategin föreskriver stöd till utvecklingen av ett mer effektivt rättsväsende och kampen mot korruption och organiserad brottslighet. Strategin anger också att Sverige kan bidra till arbetet för att stärka rättskedjan avseende utredning, åtal och verkställande av dom för dessa brott.
Det föreslagna projektet innehåller ett detaljerat resultatramverk, som har utvecklats av Europarådet i Serbien i samarbete med mottagarlandets institutioner. De föreslagna resultatområdena har valts ut på grund av deras relevans och genomförbarhet. Möjligheterna att nå målen ökas genom en nära koppling till den planerade och pågående reformprocessen inom serbiska institutioner. På grund av detta, bedöms det föreslagna projektet som den mest effektiva formen av stöd.
Medel kommer att kanaliseras via Europarådet, vilket i sin tur kommer att ingå avtal för alla nödvändiga tjänster och utföra kontrollen av användningen av medlen och organisera extern revision. Europarådet kommer att ansvara för den finansiella, administrativa förvaltningen och den operativa förvaltningen sker genom en grupp av fem CoE-experter och ett nätverk av kontakter med relevanta konsulter. Beslut kommer att fattas gemensamt med partners. Denna lösning anses mer kostnadseffektiv än alternativet, som är att implementera stödet genom upphandlade konsulttjänster.
Budgeten är rimlig i förhållande till mål och förväntade resultat. Budgeten är uppdelad i två områden: programförvaltning och aktivitetskostnader och bryts ned ytterligare i arvode och ersättningsgilla kostnader. Sammantaget motsvarar arvodet 49.7% av den totala budgeten. Av detta avser programförvaltningsavgifter 32% av den totala budgeten. Administrationskostnader uppgår till totalt 7% av den totala budgeten. De omfattar indirekta driftskostnader.
Hållbarhet har beaktats och inkluderas i olika aspekter av förslaget. Projektet kommer att involvera ett stort antal av institutioner och adekvata mekanismer ska sökas för att säkerställa fullständig överföring av ägarskap och se till att framtida hållbar kapacitet utvecklas.
Projektet är i linje med de nationellt fastställda prioriteringarna, men finansieringsmodaliteten är inte i linje med partnerns eget system, eftersom finansiell förvaltning sker helt av Europarådet. Sida bedömer det fortfarande inte som lämpligt att slussa medel genom nationella partnerinstitutioner, eftersom det inte finns någon resultatbaserad budgetering. Dessutom är en programansats ännu inte möjlig, främst på grund av bristande intresse från andra givare.
Riskerna för effektiviteten och genomförbarheten av projektet har bedömts, dokumenterats och sammanfattats i ett riskanalysregister. Riskerna har bedömts i förhållande till de förväntade resultaten och hänsyn har tagits till principerna för biståndseffektivitet.

The proposed project addresses the perceived AML/CFT regulatory shortcomings and aims to assist the authorities effectively with implementing new legislative and regulatory changes in seven proposed outcome areas. The main areas of intervention will concern AML/CFT compliance and supervision gaps in the non-financial sector (Designated Non-Financial Businesses and Professions - DNFBPs), understanding and management of terrorist financing risks within the non-profit sector, risk-based border control, beneficial ownership due diligence for some sectors, application of fit and proper test and group-wide polices, ML investigation and prosecution and confiscation of proceeds and instrumentalities of crime.
The project aims at creating and institutionalizing a change by focusing on several types of activities: 1) developing sustainable training programs for risk oversight, uniform application of effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanction, processing ML/TF cases involving natural and legal persons, securing and confiscating assets and analysing financial sector information, 2) developing procedures, criteria, methodology and indicators for risk oversight, 3) developing guidelines for processing of ML/FT cases and financial investigations; 4) assessment of risks in different areas and issuing recommendations for the improvement of primary and secondary legislation, 5) analysing IT needs in relation to financial investigations. The methodology thus addresses a sustainable medium to long-term strategic capacity development, based on building a sustainable resource base in a number of key reform areas across the government.
Overall responsibility for Project results will be in the hands of the Council of Europe, who will act as a coordinator. However, individual leadership and the commitment of individual project partners will be nurtured through joint decision-making.
The Project will start with a six-month inception phase and last 36 months.

tag.narrative: 16.4 - By 2030, significantly reduce illicit financial and arms flows, strengthen the recovery and return of stolen assets and combat all forms of organized crime.
16.4 - Till 2030 avsevärt minska de olagliga finansiella flödena och vapenflödena, öka möjligheterna att återvinna och återfå stulna tillgångar samt bekämpa alla former av organiserad brottslighet.

title.narrative: Decision CoE Action against Money Laundering

description.narrative: This Conclusion on Performance is based on the Annual Report for 2020. The report has been prepared in accordance with the Agreement between Sida and the Council of Europe. It summarizes the obtained and expected results in relation to the agreed results framework and includes information about the deviation from the original work plan. The revised work plan that was expected to be attached to this report was delivered prior to the report, in connection with the Steering Committee meeting, which took place on 27 November 2020. The revised work plan was approved at the Steering Committee following the agreed procedure. The originally agreed six-month inception period for this project (January - June 2020) was extended with Sida's approval to allow for adequate completion of preparatory activities that were affected by the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic. The inception phase also coincided with the parliamentary elections in June 2020 and the protracted formation of the new government, which led to further delays. However, the CoE has been able to set up the project team and initiate the first set of activities. The report argues that the delays did not affect the project rationale. The theory of change and the results framework remain relevant. Slight fine-tuning has been done in response to the changes in the policy and legislative environment. These modifications primarily reflect the adoption of new importance pieces of legislation aiming at better adjustment and alignment of the national legislative and institutional framework to prevent and suppress money laundering and terrorist financing. These are: amendments to the Law on the Prevention of Money Laundering and Financing of Terrorism to include a definition of virtual currencies (December 2019), a new Strategy on Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism for the period 2020-2024 (February 2020), amendments to the Law on Games of Chance (February 2020) and the Law on Real Estate and Trade and Lease (December 2019). The Law on Digital Assets was adopted at the end of 2020. During the reporting period, the CoE managed to complete the necessary recruitment of project personnel and conduct meetings with the national counterparts in order to set the proper timeline of activities in the revised work plan and sequence them in the order of priority and in line with current needs of the beneficiaries while also taking into account the restrictive measures relating to COVID-19 pandemic. Due to the anticipated and announced changes in some of the key positions in various partner institutions following the elections and the changes in the government set-up, the project team has indicated the need to follow up with the beneficiary institutions to once again validate the work plan regarding short-term institutional priorities. The recruitments of the Senior Project Officer and Project Assistant were completed, setting the nucleus of the project team. After serious delays in the recruitment of the International Project Manager mainly due to the COVID-19 pandemic, Sida indicated that the CoE could consider restructuring the project team to avoid further delays and still allow for smooth implementation. This suggestion is under consideration. During the reporting period, the relevance of the project was discussed and agreed with the key counterparts. Fight against economic crime including the fight against corruption and money laundering and terrorist financing have been formally recognized by the project partners as the priority tasks of the government. This was demonstrated by a rather high-level participation at the first project Steering Committee which took place on 27 November 2020, where three assistant ministers were present (Economy, Finance and Trade), confirming their support to the project. This meeting resulted in the adoption of the ToR for the Steering Committee and the revised work plan. Two key lines of action have been launched during the reporting period in the area of effective implementation of the Anti-Money Laundering/Counter Terrorist Financing (AML/CFT) measures by the non-financial sector including the legal professionals and virtual assets service providers. A technical paper has been developed to provide guidance to the competent authorities in Serbia on applying risk-based approach to AML/CFT supervision of Virtual Assets and Virtual Asset Service Providers (VASPs). This action followed the adoption of the Law on Digital Assets in December 2020 and it is expected to support the new supervisors, the National Bank of Serbia and the Securities' Commission, to better prepare for its implementation as of June 2021. The project also initiated the development of a training manual and curriculum for the legal professionals on controlling sector-specific money laundering and terrorist financing risks in close cooperation with the Bar Association of Serbia. This training is to be executed through the Judicial Academy with a view to creating a pool of legal experts who will be able to ensure the sustainable training of lawyers across Serbia. During the reporting period, the CoE made an effort to liaise and coordinate with other ongoing initiatives in this area (US Embassy/USAID, UNODC, Regional Asset Recovery & Anti-Corruption Advisor for the Western Balkans and the EU project “Enhancing the Quality and Efficiency of Suspicious Transactions Reporting (STR) and Administration for the Prevention of Money Laundering (APML) core functions” implemented by KPMG), which lead to the adjustment of several action areas in order to better address the needs of the beneficiary institutions, but also build on the expertise and assistance that was already provided.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
